author: Mike Heika
title: Heika: Stars' seventh straight loss to Avalanche in Colorado sees Niemi crash back down to earth
text:
Watch highlights of the game here.
Watch Lindy Ruff talk to the media here.
DENVER -- The Pepsi Center is giving the Stars indigestion ... or maybe worse, a long winter of heartache.
Dallas lost for the seventh straight time in this building, and did it in fizzling fashion Saturday night. The Stars squandered a 3-1 lead and were blown out by the Avalanche 6-3.
But as much as the final score was tough to swallow, the fact the game was tied heading into the third period had Stars head coach Lindy Ruff fuming.
"It's disappointing. It's embarrassing, worse than disappointing," Ruff said. "It's a 3-3 game with 20 minutes left, that's not good enough. They won the battles and their best players were the best players and ours weren't."
Gabriel Landeskog finished with two goals and two assists, Nathan MacKinnon had a goal and two assists and Alex Tanguay chipped in two pretty assists for Colorado. The Stars were led by two goals from Cody Eakin and one from rookie Mattias Janmark.
"We had 20 minutes left in the hockey game, and they wanted it more than us and outbattled us, and that pretty much sums it up," said Stars captain Jamie Benn, who had an assist but finished minus-2.
Dallas had a 33-28 advantage in shots on goal and was solid for the first 30 minutes of the game. Janmark scored just 20 seconds into the game, scoring on his first shot for the second game in a row. The rookie scored 1:39 into his NHL debut and then broke open on a Jason Demers pass on his first shift against Colorado.
Janmark beat Semyon Varlamov and an Avalanche team that had squandered a 4-1 lead in a 5-4 loss to Minnesota on Thursday was on the ropes. MacKinnon tied the game, but then Eakin scored twice to put the Stars in the driver's seat.
Boosted up to the top line and given power play time, Eakin was opportunistic. He scored off a rebound set up by Benn and Tyler Seguin, and then followed that up with a power play goal off a nice pass from Demers.
With Antti Niemi riding a hot streak and the Stars playing with confidence, it seemed the team was off to the second step of that fast start it so desired.
But then Colorado came back with power play goals from Erik Johnson and Jarome Iginla, and the battle was on. Tied 3-3 after two periods, the Avalanche ran away with the game. John Mitchell set up camp in front of the goal and waited for the puck. It found its way to him, and he beat Niemi for the go-ahead goal at the 8:11 mark. Mitchell was left alone by the Stars' team defense in a moment that characterized the third period for Dallas.
Landeskog then scored on a one-timer 47 seconds later, and the game was pretty much over. Varlamov held the fort, and Landeskog added another goal to make Niemi's night pretty terrible.
After stopping 37 shots in a shutout on Thursday, he allowed six goals on 28 shots Saturday.
"It's a long season, and we have to be sharp in these situations," Niemi said. "It was 3-3 going to the third; we've got to be better there."
In fact, the Stars have to be much better. If they want to win the Central -- or just make the playoffs -- they need to solve the mystery that is Pepsi Center.
"We learned our lesson last year. These guys had our number last year, and we had a pretty bad record in our division, and it makes a pretty big difference coming down the stretch," Benn said. "We don't want to be looking back ever. We wanted to change that, but it wasn't there."
Dallas last won in Denver on Feb.4, 2013, and most of those seven losses haven't been close.
"At this point, it just sucks to lose this game," said Jason Spezza when asked if the losing streak stings. "We know we've got to beat these guys, we know we've got to beat the division, but we just have to ge t back to work."
